subject: Re: Dynamically discovering classes in a package. (was: Re: [junit] Why is it considered an error if there is no test in the file?)
msgSnippet: David, ... TestNG has code that does that (you can basically specify run all the classes in the package com.foo.mytests , and we even support wildcards).
messageBody:
David,

On 11/9/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> The ability to, with even just 80% reliability, get at runtime all of the
> classes in a package, without having to parse directories of source code,
> would be great for JUnit and other packages. Of course, Java makes 100%
> reliability impossible, but it would seem that examining the classpath
> could
> allow some magic to be worked. It would also seem the kind of problem
> that
> someone out there may have already solved. Anyone have a pointer?


TestNG has code that does that (you can basically specify 'run all the
classes in the package "com.foo.mytests"', and we even support wildcards).
Not sure where your 80% figure comes from, because I can promise you it
works 100% of the time (even though it relies on a few things that are only
loosely documented in the ClassLoader API).

Feel free to grab the code.

--
Cédric
